First, the error of unreal dharmas producing seeds.

The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra, fascicle 54, says: It is not due to their having substance.
If they are produced from different seeds, then they have substance.
Therefore, it contradicts the holy teachings. Third, the error of unreal dharmas being able to perfume.
Having already established the extremely subtle as a mental object,
the seen part is false and is admitted to be able to perfume seeds.

This contradicts the second opinion that false dharmas are like non-existent causes and conditions. The third opinion is that the seen part and the seeing part are the same or different according to the circumstances.

the seen part and the seeing part are the same seed.
Because they have no self-nature, the seen part is also false.
They do not perfume seeds separately.
They only follow the power of the seeing part and perfume seeds together.
For example, when perceiving the five sense organs, which are real entities,
the seen part and the seeing part are born from different seeds.
Because the eighteen sense fields are definitely different causes, they are not mixed up. However, the seen part and the substance,
one opinion says they are the same seed.
One opinion says they are different seeds.

Because the seeds of the direct and indirect causes are different. For example, when perceiving the eighth consciousness, the seen part and substance are the same seed.

Because the image and the real entity are born from the same seeds.

Why not have two bodies with the same sense faculties, etc.? If the image is a conceptual construction when the six consciousnesses are conditions,ğŸ”½then there would be the error of one kind of seeds producing both the real and the conceptual.

Because they are able to perfume.

Another explanation: If the image and the real entity are born from the same seeds,
then like the eye faculty, etc., the transformation of the eighth consciousness is a condition as cause, and therefore has the real function of the faculties.
If the image is born from the sixth consciousness as a condition,
although it is born from the same seeds as the original real entity,
because the seeing part of the sixth consciousness is the condition for its arising,
it is categorized as a transformation of discrimination and therefore lacks real function.
It is not without substance, and therefore there is no error of the real and the conceptual being born from the same seeds.

However, there are distinctions in seeds. The nature may be the same as the view, or the nature may be the same while the seeds are distinguished. Or the nature of the seen part follows the nature of the seeing part and the substance, so the nature is not fixed. Or although there is a substance,

However, there are distinctions in the seeds of the same and different natures. The nature may be the same as the view, or the nature may be the same but the bonds and seeds are different. The Tripiá¹­aka Master [Xuanzang] composed a verse to illustrate this distinction, saying:
The nature of the objective realm does not follow the mind.
The solitary image only comes from the seeing.
The substance that accompanies the essence is common to the root.
The nature, seeds, etc. follow as appropriate.
The explanation of this verse is as described in the Essentials of the Teaching.

Because the meaning is slightly difficult, it is further expanded. First, the objective realm of nature is determined, and then it is shown not to follow. What is called the objective realm of nature?
It is born from the seeds of reality.
It has real substance and function.

The mind that can cognize it obtains its own characteristics, which is called the objective realm of nature. For example, when the body is in the desire realm, the objective realm transformed by the eighth consciousness is the five sense objects.
Because it is born from real seeds and transformed by conditional causes,
it is called the objective realm of nature.
The five consciousnesses and the sixth consciousness associated with them,
when they take as their object a present thing, obtain the particular inherent characteristics of the object.
The images of these consciousnesses are also called real objects,
because the images are derived from the real objects.ğŸ”½The other dharmas can be understood by analogy.
In this way, the images of consciousness are of four kinds and do not follow the mind.
They do not follow the mind in being good or soiled.
They do not follow the mind in being bound to the same realm.

They do not follow the mind in being born of the same species.ğŸ”½They do not follow the mind in being retribution, etc.ğŸ”½Even though the images of consciousness are of the same realm and class as the mind that perceives them, they are not the same in stage, etc.
They are not the same because of the power of the perceiving mind.
They are called real objects that do not follow the mind.
The five consciousnesses are of three natures.
The real objects and images are both nondetermined.
They do not follow the five consciousnesses, which are of three natures.
The other dharmas can be understood by analogy.ğŸ”½Even though the five consciousnesses are of the nondetermined nature,
the objects of the five consciousnesses are of the same nature as the consciousnesses.
The seen and seeing parts each maintain their own nature.
It is not that they become indeterminate only because they follow the mind that is able to perceive them.
The rest can be understood in the same way. If the scattered consciousness of the individual mind perceives the five sense objects of its own realm, etc.,
It is only the nature of those objects abiding in themselves, not the nature of obtaining themselves.
However, the nature, species, etc. are also the same as the five conditions.
Explaining the second sentence.
It means that the perceiving mind only transforms the image alone.
There is no separate original substance as the second.
Although there is an original substance,
The image part does not arise from the original substance.
Because that original substance is a non-arising dharma, etc.
These image parts,
And the image parts manifested by the five aggregates associated with the eighth consciousness perceived by the sixth consciousness,
Only arise from the same species as the perceiving mind.
Therefore, they are called solitary shadows that only come from the seeing part.
Like the solitary mental consciousness perceiving empty flowers, the unconditioned, etc.

All are the same in kind as the seeing part, or they are the third alternative, having as objects the unconditioned, or they are the fourth alternative, having as objects the five that are associated with the eighth consciousness.
Or they are the fourth alternative, having as objects such things as flowers in the sky. These images are of four kinds, all derived from the seeing part.
The first is derived from the seeing part and is the same in being good or defiled.
The second is the same in realm.
The third is the same in kind.
The fourth is the same in being retribution or nonretribution.
Since the images that do not arise from real objects are transformations of mental consciousness,
these images are the same as the perceiving mind in realm, stage, etc.
The images are subsumed in the seeing part.ğŸ”½Therefore they are called â€œunique images derived from the seeing part only.â€
Question: Are the images of such things as flowers in the sky form or mind?
If they are form, how can they be the same as mind in realm, stage, etc.?

Answer: When falsely imagined, they are imagined form.
When generally perceived,
although not imagined, they are of the same class as imagined form.
They are also included in that.
Because they are of the same species, they have the same nature of consciousness. Moreover, the name of the imagined is the meaning of discrimination.
It is not only the mind of grasping.
Otherwise, there would be the fault of not including all dharmas. Because of a fever that destroys the eyes, etc., one sees yellow when there is no yellow.
Seeing yellow when there is no yellow is the sixth consciousness.
It is not the eye consciousness, because it grasps its own characteristics.
Although this is not the mind of grasping dharmas,
it can also be called the imagined color.

However, the seeds that are perfumed are included according to the substance of the original object. The question is: As for the subsequently acquired cognition that takes the various unconditioned dharmas as its objects, the common characteristics and specific characteristics,
and takes as its objects the empty flowers, rabbit horns, etc. that are the objects of ordinary beings,
what category are they included in? The answer is: The various images that are the objects of the unconditioned dharmas, etc. are included in the common characteristics of dharmas.
Because their substance is false.
Because the common characteristics of dharmas are broad.
Unlike the contaminated [dharmas], they are not falsely grasped. Or, the objects of empty flowers, etc. are also included in the imagined color.
Because the word imagined means discrimination.
Question: When the body is in the upper realms and the divine eye of a higher god perceives forms of the desire realm,ğŸ”½to what category does the appearing part of those forms belong?
Answer: One says:
Although they are not unique images, they also arise from seeing.
Because those forms of concentration do not arise in the lower realms,

they are bound to different realms.ğŸ”½They arise from seeing and are bound to the same realm, but not to the same species.ğŸ”½If that is so, how can they be objects of one's own characteristics?ğŸ”½Answer: They are said to obtain their own nature by relying on the original substance.ğŸ”½If that is so, then the images and seeing of subsequent attainment that perceive the unconditioned, etc. should be different.

the upper realms can manifest as the lower realms.

it is because it perceives the form of the fruit of karma in the desire realm.

Just as the eye consciousness produced by the eye of the fruit of karma has the perceived part of the form of the fruit of the superior path.ğŸ”½How can it be that the mind of the fruit of the superior path does not have the form of the fruit of karma?ğŸ”½The first two explanations are superior. Answer: Form aggregates are not objects of cognition,

It is permissible to establish the dharmas not directly associated with mind.
As for saying there are twenty-four, it is established according to the superior.
Like the various mental factors established according to the superior.

Some say they are bonds of the lower stages,
because they are perfumed and formed by the appearing images of the lower stages.
Because they are not the intrinsic nature of defilements, they do not increase.
However, they are difficult to fathom.
Explaining the third line.
That is, the mind that is able to take as an object takes the object as its object.
There is a supporting substance, but it does not obtain its own nature.
This part of the image is not determined in terms of its nature.
Sometimes it comes from the mind that is able to take as an object.
Sometimes it comes from the object that is taken as an object.
Seeds are also not determined.ğŸ”½Sometimes the substance has the same seeds.
Sometimes the seeing part has the same seeds.
Sometimes they have separate seeds.
It is called having a substance and is common to both the root and the secondary.
For example, the seventh consciousness takes the eighth consciousness as its object.
This is the case of subsuming the image under the seeing part, which has the nature of being covered.ğŸ”½From the substance, it has the nature of being uncovered.

Answer: Although the freely taken objects are called images,

Before the free use, they only take their own objects,
therefore it is said that the five consciousnesses take objects by nature.ğŸ”½If the independent mental consciousness takes objects, it also has the fourth category.
Some say:
The images with support are both conceptual and original.

If it is like the present image, which is separate from the substance and separate from seeing, then it is included in the dharmas of similar class. Question: If that is so, then similar class should be generally real. Answer: There is no error in considering it so.
Just as the member of name-and-form is only the seeds, which are indeterminate.
This does not prevent the seventh consciousness from also being included in name. Another interpretation says it is not so.
The seventh consciousness is in name-and-form, but in terms of the present, it is not a member.
Similar class is not associated.

then the dharmas of similar class that are neither mind nor form
are all images that cannot be objects.
The seeds, etc., should be the dharmas of similar class.
Since they are not so, how can this be so?
Therefore it cannot be said that it is determined by being separate from seeing and substance.
Because it is definitely one of the two,
it is not the dharmas of similar class.
This explanation is correct.
Therefore it is determined that the seventh consciousness, whose image is separate from seeing and substance, is included in the dharmas of similar class.
This is not the correct explanation. Now I will further explain.
It is said that the images of the five consciousnesses are all based on real objects, and the images of the sixth consciousness are of two kinds.
It is like the relationship between the pure and impure dharmas as objects of each other.
It is like the seventh consciousness taking the eighth consciousness as its object.
The pure part of the image is good and pure, following the seeing part, while the part of the image that is the real basis is indeterminate.
The rest can be understood by analogy.
Therefore it is said that the images of the five consciousnesses are always associated with real objects.
Moreover, even if there is a real basis,
the image and the seeing part are sometimes associated and sometimes not.
As for the conditioned and unconditioned, pure and impure,
the meaning should be considered by analogy.
If we rely on the original explanation,
when the pure and impure dharmas, etc., are objects of each other,
it is the fourth alternative.
As for the natures, seeds, etc., following as appropriate,
